snippet: The incident at a Silicon Valley power substation underscored concerns about the vulnerability of the country’s electrical grid and prompted debate over whether it was an act of terrorism.
abstract: Incident at a Silicon Valley power substation underscores concerns about the vulnerability of the country’s electrical grid and prompts debate over whether it was an act of terrorism; on April 16, 2013, one or more people methodically cut communication cables near a Pacific Gas & Electric substation in San Jose, sprayed more than 100 rifle bullets and knocked out 17 of the station’s 23 transformers before fleeing and avoiding capture.

byline.original: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and MATTHEW L. WALD
byline.contributor: Norimitsu Onishi reported from San Francisco, and Matthew L. Wald from Washington. Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The incident at a Silicon Valley power substation underscored concerns about the vulnerability of the country’s electrical grid and prompted debate over whether it was an act of terrorism.

headline.main: Months Later, Sniper Attack at Power Hub Still a Mystery
headline.print_headline: Months Later, Sniper Attack at Power Hub Still a Mystery
